Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge correctly applied the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Dr. Udwadia was physically present in Canada for 717 days during the four-year period preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days (three out of four years)
Decision_Outcome: The citizenship judge's decision was found to be unreasonable
Remedy_Requested: The Minister appealed the grant of citizenship
Court_Ruling: The Federal Court overturned the citizenship judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Applied for citizenship while not meeting the statutory physical presence requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet the three-out-of-four-year residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Legal_Standard: Two-step test: (1) establishing residence in Canada; (2) meeting the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Assessment_Factor: Duration and continuity of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: The citizenship judge failed to determine when Dr. Udwadia established residence in Canada
Evidence_Used: Record of Dr. Udwadia’s physical presence (717 days) in Canada
Legal_Provision_Cited: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act – three out of four years
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence in Canada as documented in immigration records
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the granted citizenship and requirement to reapply
Governing_Rule: Applicant must reside in Canada for 1,095 days within the four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of determination on when residence was established; insufficient days of presence
Outcome: Appeal allowed; citizenship revoked; Dr. Udwadia must reapply after meeting requirements
Harm_Assessment: Granting citizenship contrary to statutory requirements undermines integrity of citizenship process
Cause_Description: Dr. Udwadia's citizenship was granted despite not meeting the statutory residency requirement
Evidence_Handling: Physical presence data was reviewed but residence establishment was not properly assessed
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence
Evidence_Issues: Subjective assessment used without objective determination of residence commencement
Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act – Residency Requirement (3 of 4 years)
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evaluation of when residence began; focus only on subjective intent
Decision_Rationale: The judge failed to apply the two-step test correctly, particularly step one (establishing residence); decision was unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to objectively assess establishment of residence despite clear physical absence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in reviewing administrative decision
